COLLETTE*, V. DEREMINCE-MATHIEU, J. J. VERBIST, Z. GABELICA, J. B. NAGY and E. G. DEROUANE Oroupe de Chimie-Physique, Facultes Universitaires N.D. de la Paix, 61 rue de Bruxelles, B-5000 Namur (Belgium) (Received March 10, 1986; accepted May 11, 1987) Summary Bismuth uranates with Bi/U ratio = 2 were prepared by various methods, including precipitation by ammonia (at controlled pH) or evapora- tion of uranium and bismuth nitrates. Simultaneous use of thermoanalytical techniques (TG, DTG, DTA) led to the proposal of mechanisms which explain the formation of Bi2UOfi. In particular, DTA results revealed the existence of interactions between base reactants favouring the formation of Bi2UOe. Combined X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) were used to investigate the surface composi- tion of the catalysts. The presence of superficial Bi203 was detected, in agreement with the reduction of the surface energy of the particles. Introduction Uranium-based mixed oxides have promising properties as heteroge- neous catalysts. In particular, uranium antimonates (U-Sb-0) were regarded as essential components of highly active catalysts for the allylic oxidation of alkenes, especially for the ammoxidation of propylene to acrylonitrile [1 - 6]. Uranium-molybdenum oxides were reported to be active for the selec- tive oxidation ofisobutene [7]. Bismuth uranate, Bi2UOe, was successfully used to catalyse the conver- sion of toluene to benzene at 400 - 500 C [8 -10]. Although very active, Bi2U06 showed little selectivity in the oxidation of toluene, unless the reac- tion is conducted in absence of gaseous oxygen. During this process, Bi2U06 can lose 60% of its oxygen content, which may be restored by involving molecular oxygen in a separate operation. The importance of such oxygen- donor properties was emphasized in oxidation reactions where redox mechanisms account for the catalytic processes. *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-6102/87/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 16 Bi2UOfi is usually prepared by a solid-state reaction between equivalent amounts of Q:-Bi203 and a-UOs at 800 C [11]. It can also be synthesized from Bi203-a:N03'yH20 and U03-;!cNH3-yH20 precursors, precipitated separately by ammonia from aqueous solutions, then admixed in water, heated at 90 -100 C under vigorous stirring and finally calcined at 500 C [9]. As part of an extensive study on the activity of various Bi U mixed oxides used as catalysts for oxidation reactions, this first paper in a series describes and compares various preparation methods leading to bismuth uranates. Combined thermoanalytical methods were used to investigate the physical and chemical transformations occurring during the calcination of the precursors and to elucidate the mechanisms governing the formation of the active phases at high temperatures. Specific information about the surface composition of the so-obtained crystalline compounds was inferred using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) techniques. Experimental Catalyst preparation Three preparation methods were used to obtain bismuth uranate precursors with atomic ratio Bi/U = 2. (A) Commercial Bi(N03)3-5H20 and U02(N03)2-6H20 (Merck P.A.) were dissolved in 1 M HNC>3. The solutions were added dropwise to an ammonia buffer solution (NH3/NH4d:pH = 9.0). Simultaneous precipitation of reactants occured during the addition (final pH = 8.5). (B) The precursor was obtained by adding NF^OH (25%) to a solution containing U02(N03)2'6H20 and Bi(NC>3)3-5H20 predissolved in 1 M HNC>3. The continuous pH increase led to the selective precipitation of the reactants (final pH= 8.0). (C)Bi(N03)3-5H20 and UO^NO^- 6^0 solutions (1 M HNO^) are slowly evaporated until dryness under vigorous stirring. The two precipitates from procedures A and B were filtered and washed extensively with hot water until complete elimination of residual ammonium salts. All the precursors were dried overnight at 90 C, and finally calcined in air during 5 h at 500, 700 and 900 C, respectively. Characterization methods X-ray diffraction (XRD) powder patterns were obtained with a Philips PW 1730 diffractometer, at room temperature, using Ni-filtered Cu Ka radia- tion. Thermoanalytical methods (simultaneous thermogravimetry (TG), differential thermogravimetry (DTG), and differential thermal analysis (DTA)) were used to elucidate the mechanisms governing the formation of the catalytically active phases from precursors at high temperatures. About 17 50 mg of sample were heated (20 C min"1) in Pt crucibles from 20 to 900 C, either in static air or under dry N; flow (30 ml min~1), in a Stanton- Redcroft STA-780 thermal analyzer. a-A^Os was used as DTA reference. Intermediate solid phases were identified at different stages of the heating process by XRD. The surface composition of the final crystalline phases was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The samples were deposited on a gold-plated sample holder, and XPS spectra were recorded on a Hewlett- Packard 5950A spectrometer using monochromatized Al Ka radiation (hv= 1486.6 eV). An electron flood-gun was used to compensate surface charging effects on non-conductive samples. Semi-quantitative information about the atomic surface composition was deduced by integration of the uranium and bismuth ^f-,/^ peaks. The corrective factor was determined from the spectra of pure bismuth and uranyl nitrates, recorded under strictly identical conditions: NM/NU = Iw^JIv^,, X 2.22 An essentially identical correction factor can be obtained by using the full intensity expression, including the photoionisation cross-section, the asym- metry parameter factor, the analyser transmission factor, and the mean escape depth of the ejected electrons, both factors being a function of the electron kinetic energy [6]. The Bi and U contents of the solid phases were analyzed by energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX). Samples were glued on a brass support and examined with a Jeol SEM microscope (JSM-35) connected to an energy dispersion X-ray analyzer, equipped with a high resolution semiconductor detector. EDX, which probes both elements at a depth of 2 to 5 /xm, can be considered as a bulk analytical method for small particles, while larger parti- cles are only partly probed in their outer layer. Quantitative analyses were achieved using calibration curves obtained by analyzing under identical conditions homogeneous mixtures of pure Bi2UOe and o;-Bi203 or U30g, having Bi/U ratios between 1 and 4. Preparation B Thermal analysis, performed on the pure uranium and bismuth com- pounds prepared using the same method, allowed the identification of the exact nature of the mixed precursor. The decomposition pattern of the pure ammonium uranate U03-0.7NH3-H20 at high temperature is quite similar to that characterizing the U03'0.8NH3'H20 precursor obtained through procedure A and given in Fig. 1. The solid products stemming from the hydrolysis of bismuth nitrate are more difficult to identify, as revealed by a recent review published by Lazarini [18]. Eighteen compounds are quoted in the literature, their actual composition depending on the methods of preparation used and the final pH. All these products are obtained by adding large quantities of water to a solution of Bi(N03)3 in HN03 (initial pH < 1.0). In our experimental conditions, a neutralization of such a solu- tion by ammonia can further complicate the nature of the products, as NH3 can be partly incorporated into the precipitate. Samples prepared according to methods B and C reveal an excess of Bi at the surface (Bi/U > 2). This suggests the presence of residual Bi-fl^ covering the particles. This hypothesis is substantiated by thermal analysis, which detects the DTA effect associated with the Bi^'0^ phase transition during calcination of precursors B and C. This shows the difficulty in obtaining pure Bi2UOe in our experimental conditions. Segregation of this oxide is directed by surface tension phenomena: the constituent having the lowest free energy tends to migrate to the surface of the particle to reduce the superficial energy. This should occur above the Tammann temperature (0.52 7m (in K), where I'm is the melting point) of the oxide, i.e. at a tem- perature at which it starts to acquire an apparent mobility. Bi^O^ becomes mobile enough to migrate at approximately 320 C to the surface of the more refractory compounds such as BizUOg (estimated melting point = 1300 C [9]). The presence of Bi^Oy at the surface might have significant influence on the catalytic properties of these systems. Surface and bulk compositions of catalysts prepared by method A con- firm the loss of bismuth during calcination up to 590 C, due to partial BiCl3 evaporation (Bi/U < 2 for the catalysts calcined at 700 and 900 C). The bulk composition of the sample prepared at 500 C (Bi/U = 1.58) approximated by EDX can be explained by an early partial decomposition of BiOCI which leads to the formation of Bi^UOf, traces (detected by XRD at 500 C). Conclusions Three synthesis procedures, including precipitation by ammonia or evaporation of base reactants, were used to prepare bismuth uranate catalysts with Bi/U = 2. The formation of BizUOg using precipitation by 27 ammonia and evaporation of nitrates is already achieved at 500 C. A further calcination at 900 C probably results in a slight modification of the surface composition and in an increase of the Bi^UOg crystallinity. Synthesis by coprecipitation at controlled pH (NH3-NH4C1 buffer) leads to the formation of BiOCI in the precursor, which finally decomposes into Bi2C>3 and volatile Bida at high temperatures. The further formation of Bi2UOfi is delayed up to 700 C. The Bi/U atomic ratios are modified and an excess of UaOg is detected by XRD at 700 C. Thermal analysis allowed elucidation of the mechanisms of formation of Bi2U06 under the different experimental conditions. In particular, this technique revealed various interactions between base reactants favouring the formation of the U Bi mixed oxides, and the stabilization during calcination of crystalline phases such as jS-Bi^. No thermal effects due to BizUOg formation were observed. The difficulty in obtaining pure Bi2U06. in our experimental conditions was emphasized by XPS and explained in terms of the presence of a superficial Bi203 layer. Catalytic tests for the oxidation of CO by 02 and/or by NO will be the object of future investiga- tions in relation to these experiments. Bismuth uranates with Bi/U ratio = 2 were prepared by various methods, including precipitation by ammonia (at controlled pH) or evaporation of uranium and bismuth nitrates. Simultaneous use of thermoanalytical techniques (TG, DTG, DTA) led to the proposal of mechanisms which explain the formation of Bi2UO6. In particular, DTA results revealed the existence of interactions between base reactants favouring the formation of Bi2UO6. Combined X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) were used to investigate the surface composition of the catalysts. The presence of superficial Bi2O3 was detected, in agreement with the reduction of the surface energy of the particles. References 1 U.S. Pat. 3 308 151 (1967) to J.L. Callahan and B.
